Line 58: Line 58:
On [[June 1]], [[2005]], Google shares gained nearly 4 percent after Credit Suisse First Boston raised its price target on the stock to $350. On the same day, rumors circulated in the financial community that Google would soon be included in the [[S&P 500]]. (Source: {{Web reference | title=Google Shares Rise on New Price Target | work=L.A.Times | URL=http://www.latimes.com/business/investing/wire/sns-ap-google-price-target,1,2312669.story?coll=sns-ap-investing-headlines&ctrack=1&cset=true | date=June 1 | year=2005}}) When companies are first listed on the S&P 500 they typically experience a bump in share price. On [[June 7]], 2005, Google was valued at $80 billion, making it the world's biggest media company by stock market value (surpassing [[Time Warner]]). Later, however, the stock dipped and Time Warner again became more valuable.
On [[June 1]], [[2005]], Google shares gained nearly 4 percent after Credit Suisse First Boston raised its price target on the stock to $350. On the same day, rumors circulated in the financial community that Google would soon be included in the [[S&P 500]]. (Source: {{Web reference | title=Google Shares Rise on New Price Target | work=L.A.Times | URL=http://www.latimes.com/business/investing/wire/sns-ap-google-price-target,1,2312669.story?coll=sns-ap-investing-headlines&ctrack=1&cset=true | date=June 1 | year=2005}}) When companies are first listed on the S&P 500 they typically experience a bump in share price. On [[June 7]], 2005, Google was valued at $80 billion, making it the world's biggest media company by stock market value (surpassing [[Time Warner]]). Later, however, the stock dipped and Time Warner again became more valuable.
â
===Salaries===
+
With Google's increased size comes more competition from large mainstream technology companies. The rivalry between Microsoft and Google has been cited most often [http://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,1759,1706872,00.asp]. The two companies are increasingly offering overlapping services, such as desktop and online search, webmail and browsers. Some have even suggested that in addition to an [[Internet Explorer]] replacement Google is designing a [[List_of_Google_services_and_tools#Google_Operating_System|Google operating system]] to directly compete with [[Microsoft Windows]]. This corporate feud is most directly expressed in hiring offers and defections. Many Microsoft employees who worked on Internet Explorer have left to work for Google. In retribution, Microsoft has been touting its new [[MSN Search]] engine.
  +
